misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that N-1 is a universally safe index for accessing the 'last' element of an array, assuming that the array will always contain at least one element based on the problem context.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student fails to account for the edge case where N=0. In Java, an array of size 0 is valid, but any access to it (including index -1) results in an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException. The student's mental model does not include a safety check for the existence of elements before accessing them via an index calculated from the length.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sc.next() is sufficient for reading 'names', assuming names will always be single words without spaces.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student does not distinguish between a 'token' (word) and a 'line' (full name). In Java, sc.next() only reads up to the first whitespace. If a student's name were 'Alice Smith', the 'Smith' would remain in the buffer and be incorrectly read as the next name or cause an InputMismatchException when the program expects an integer score.
